expanded_description: This section introduces series circuits, where components are connected end-to-end forming a single path for current flow. Students will learn the characteristics of series circuits, including constant current throughout, voltage division across components, and how to calculate equivalent resistance, current, and voltage drops using Ohm's Law.

core_concept.principle: In a series circuit, components are connected in a single path so that the same current flows through each component. The total resistance is the sum of individual resistances, and the supply voltage divides among the components proportional to their resistances.
core_concept.explanation: Imagine a single-lane road with several toll booths. Every car must pass through each booth in sequence—the same number of cars per hour passes through every booth (current is constant). The total time delay (voltage drop) is the sum of delays at each booth. If one booth creates more delay (higher resistance), it uses up more of the total time budget. Series circuits work the same way: current is the same everywhere, voltage drops add up to the supply voltage, and the largest resistance gets the largest voltage share.

image.alt: Diagram of a series circuit with a battery and three resistors connected end-to-end, showing current arrows and voltage drops
image.caption: In a series circuit, the same current flows through all components

sections.introduction: A series circuit is the simplest type of electrical circuit—components connected one after another, like links in a chain. Understanding series circuits is the foundation for analyzing more complex configurations.

key_concept.definition: A series circuit is a circuit in which components are connected end-to-end, providing only one path for current flow. The same current passes through every component.
key_concept.context: If any component in a series circuit is disconnected or fails (opens), current stops flowing through the entire circuit—like a string of old Christmas lights where one burned-out bulb makes the whole string go dark.

principles.statement: In a series circuit, there is only one path for electrons to follow. The current that leaves the battery must pass through every component before returning to the battery.
principles.application: This means the current is the same at every point in the circuit. If you measure current anywhere, you get the same value.
principles.example: In a series circuit with three resistors, the current through resistor 1 equals the current through resistor 2 equals the current through resistor 3.
principles.analogy: Think of a single-loop roller coaster: the same train of cars passes every point on the track.

principles.statement: $I_{total} = I_1 = I_2 = I_3 = ...$ The current is identical in all parts of a series circuit.
principles.application: This is a key rule for solving series circuit problems—you only need to find the total current, and you know the current through each component.
principles.example: If the total current in a series circuit is $2\ \text{A}$, then every resistor carries $2\ \text{A}$.

image.alt: Diagram showing ammeters placed at different points in a series circuit all reading the same current
image.caption: Current is the same at every point in a series circuit

sections.introduction: When resistors are connected in series, their resistances add. The total resistance is simply the sum of all individual resistances.

key_concept.definition: The equivalent resistance ($R_{eq}$) of a series circuit is the sum of all individual resistances: $R_{eq} = R_1 + R_2 + R_3 + ...$
key_concept.context: This makes intuitive sense—each resistor adds more opposition to current flow, so the total resistance increases with each added resistor.

principles.statement: In series, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistances. $R_{eq} = R_1 + R_2 + R_3 + ...$
principles.application: This means adding more resistors in series always increases the total resistance, which decreases the current for a given voltage.
principles.example: Three resistors of $10\ \Omega$, $20\ \Omega$, and $30\ \Omega$ in series give $R_{eq} = 10 + 20 + 30 = 60\ \Omega$.
principles.analogy: Imagine walking through a series of crowded hallways. Each hallway adds more resistance to your progress. The total resistance is the sum of each hallway's resistance.

principles.principle: Equivalent Resistance Is Greater Than Any Individual
principles.statement: The equivalent resistance in a series circuit is always greater than the largest individual resistance.
principles.application: This helps in checking calculations—if your calculated $R_{eq}$ is smaller than one of the resistors, you've made an error.
principles.example: With resistors $100\ \Omega$ and $1\ \Omega$ in series, $R_{eq} = 101\ \Omega$, which is greater than $100\ \Omega$.

worked_examples.title: Finding Equivalent Resistance
worked_examples.problem: Three resistors with values $R_1 = 22\ \Omega$, $R_2 = 47\ \Omega$, and $R_3 = 68\ \Omega$ are connected in series. What is the total resistance?

sections.introduction: In a series circuit, the total voltage from the source divides among the components. Each resistor gets a share of the voltage proportional to its resistance.

key_concept.definition: The sum of all voltage drops around a series circuit equals the source voltage: $V_{total} = V_1 + V_2 + V_3 + ...$ This is a statement of Kirchhoff's Voltage Law.
key_concept.context: Each resistor uses up some of the electrical potential energy, so the voltage decreases as you move around the circuit.

principles.statement: The voltage drop across each resistor in a series circuit is given by $V_n = I \times R_n$, where $I$ is the same for all resistors. The largest resistance gets the largest voltage drop.
principles.application: This is called the voltage divider principle. You can find the voltage across any resistor if you know the current or the ratio of resistances.
principles.example: In a series circuit with $10\ \Omega$ and $20\ \Omega$ resistors and a $30\ \text{V}$ battery, the $20\ \Omega$ resistor gets twice the voltage of the $10\ \Omega$ resistor.
principles.analogy: Think of a series of waterfalls. Each waterfall drops some height (voltage). The total drop from top to bottom is the sum of all individual drops.

principles.statement: For two resistors in series, the voltage across $R_1$ is $V_1 = V_{total} \times \frac{R_1}{R_1 + R_2}$. Similarly, $V_2 = V_{total} \times \frac{R_2}{R_1 + R_2}$.
principles.application: This formula is useful for designing circuits that need a specific voltage from a higher supply.

worked_examples.title: Finding Voltage Drops
worked_examples.problem: A series circuit has a $24\ \text{V}$ battery and three resistors: $R_1 = 10\ \Omega$, $R_2 = 20\ \Omega$, $R_3 = 30\ \Omega$. Find the current and the voltage drop across each resistor.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Current calculation and voltage division in series.

worked_examples.title: Using Voltage Divider Formula
worked_examples.problem: Two resistors, $R_1 = 120\ \Omega$ and $R_2 = 180\ \Omega$, are connected in series across a $15\ \text{V}$ battery. Find the voltage across $R_2$ using the voltage divider formula.

sections.introduction: Power in series circuits distributes among components based on their resistance. The total power supplied by the source equals the sum of power dissipated by all resistors.

key_concept.definition: Total power in a series circuit is the sum of power dissipated by each component: $P_{total} = P_1 + P_2 + P_3 + ...$. Power for each resistor can be calculated using $P = I^2R$, $P = VI$, or $P = V^2/R$.
key_concept.context: Since current is constant in series, the resistor with the largest resistance dissipates the most power because $P = I^2R$.

principles.statement: In a series circuit, power is proportional to resistance: $P \propto R$ because $I$ is constant and $P = I^2R$. The largest resistor dissipates the most power.
principles.application: This is opposite to parallel circuits, where the smallest resistor dissipates the most power.
principles.example: In the previous example with $0.4\ \text{A}$ current, $P_1 = 0.4^2 \times 10 = 1.6\ \text{W}$, $P_2 = 0.4^2 \times 20 = 3.2\ \text{W}$, $P_3 = 0.4^2 \times 30 = 4.8\ \text{W}$. The largest resistor ($30\ \Omega$) dissipates the most power.

principles.statement: Total power can be calculated directly from the source: $P_{total} = V_{total} \times I$, or $P_{total} = I^2 R_{eq}$, or $P_{total} = V_{total}^2 / R_{eq}$.
principles.application: This provides a check: the sum of individual powers should equal the total power from the source.
principles.example: In the same circuit, $P_{total} = 24 \times 0.4 = 9.6\ \text{W}$, and $1.6 + 3.2 + 4.8 = 9.6\ \text{W}$, confirming the calculation.

worked_examples.title: Power Calculation in Series
worked_examples.problem: A series circuit has a $12\ \text{V}$ battery and two resistors: $R_1 = 15\ \Omega$ and $R_2 = 25\ \Omega$. Find the power dissipated by each resistor and the total power.

sections.introduction: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law (KVL) is a fundamental principle that formalizes how voltage behaves in any circuit loop, including series circuits.

key_concept.definition: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law states that the sum of all voltage drops around any closed loop in a circuit equals the sum of all voltage rises (or the total source voltage). In equation form: $\sum V = 0$ around a closed loop.
key_concept.context: This is a consequence of energy conservation—the energy per charge supplied by the source must equal the energy per charge used by the components.

principles.statement: For a simple series circuit with one voltage source, KVL gives: $V_{source} = V_1 + V_2 + V_3 + ...$
principles.application: This is the rule we've been using—voltage drops add up to the source voltage.
principles.example: If a $9\ \text{V}$ battery powers three resistors, and you measure $V_1 = 2\ \text{V}$, $V_2 = 3\ \text{V}$, then $V_3$ must be $9 - 2 - 3 = 4\ \text{V}$.

principles.statement: When tracing a loop, voltage gains (from negative to positive through a source) are positive, and voltage drops (across resistors in the direction of current) are negative.
principles.application: This formal sign convention ensures KVL works for complex circuits with multiple sources.
principles.example: Going around a series circuit: $+V_{battery} - V_{R1} - V_{R2} - V_{R3} = 0$

worked_examples.title: Using KVL to Find Unknown Voltage
worked_examples.problem: In a series circuit, a $15\ \text{V}$ battery is connected to three resistors. The voltage across $R_1$ is $3.5\ \text{V}$ and across $R_2$ is $6.2\ \text{V}$. What is the voltage across $R_3$?

sections.section_title: Advantages and Disadvantages of Series Circuits
sections.introduction: Series circuits have both useful applications and significant limitations. Understanding these helps in choosing the right circuit configuration.

characteristics: Easy to add voltage drops using voltage divider
classifications.behavior: Series circuits are useful when you need the same current through multiple components, or when you want to divide voltage among components.

examples.explanation: Sensors often use series resistors to create a specific voltage for measurement.
Putting a resistor in series with an LED limits current to a safe value.
Some decorative lights use series connections for simplicity.

characteristics: If one component fails (opens), entire circuit stops working
All components must operate at the same current
Adding more components increases total resistance, decreasing current
Voltage drops can be uneven if resistances differ
classifications.behavior: The main drawback is lack of redundancy—one failure disables everything. Also, components cannot operate independently.

examples.explanation: When one bulb burned out, the whole string went dark because they were wired in series.
While useful for increasing voltage, if one battery dies, current stops.

image.alt: Comparison showing series circuit with one broken component causing all lights to go out
image.caption: The main disadvantage of series circuits: one open component stops all current

sections.introduction: Despite their limitations, series circuits appear in many practical applications.

categories.description: Creating specific voltages from a higher supply.

examples.explanation: Many sensors (like thermistors or photoresistors) change resistance with environment. In a series voltage divider, the changing voltage can be measured.
Potentiometers (variable resistors) act as adjustable voltage dividers in audio equipment.
Creating a stable voltage reference for comparators and analog circuits.
A series resistor limits current through an LED to prevent damage.
Series resistors can limit charging current for batteries.

categories.description: Increasing voltage by connecting cells in series.

examples.explanation: Multiple batteries in series provide higher voltage (e.g., two $1.5\ \text{V}$ cells give $3\ \text{V}$).
Hundreds of battery cells are connected in series to achieve the high voltage needed for motors.

categories.description: Protection devices are always in series.

examples.explanation: A fuse is connected in series so that if it blows, current stops completely—protecting the circuit.
Switches are always in series to control whether current flows.

image.alt: Collage showing voltage divider circuit, LED with resistor, batteries in series, and fuse
image.caption: Series circuits are used in voltage dividers, current limiting, battery packs, and protection devices

sections.introduction: You can explore series circuit properties with simple components.

process_flow.description: Use a battery, two or three resistors, connecting wires, and a multimeter.
process_flow.mechanism: Connect the resistors end-to-end between the battery terminals. Measure current at different points and voltage across each resistor.
process_flow.result: Current is the same everywhere. Voltage drops add to battery voltage. Larger resistance has larger voltage drop.

process_flow.description: With the series circuit working, remove one resistor or disconnect a wire.
process_flow.mechanism: Observe what happens to the current (measured with ammeter) and any lights if using bulbs.
process_flow.result: Current drops to zero everywhere. The entire circuit stops working.
applications: Demonstrates that one break stops all current
Shows why series Christmas lights were problematic

process_flow.description: Build a voltage divider with two resistors. Measure the voltage between them.
process_flow.mechanism: Use $R_1 = 1\ \text{k}\Omega$ and $R_2 = 1\ \text{k}\Omega$ first, then try different ratios.
process_flow.result: With equal resistors, voltage at the midpoint is half the supply. With different ratios, voltage divides proportionally.

sections.introduction: Here are frequent misunderstandings about series circuits.

principles.principle: Misconception: Current gets 'used up' as it goes through resistors
principles.statement: Students sometimes think current decreases after passing through a resistor.
principles.application: Current is the same everywhere in a series circuit. Charge is conserved—electrons don't disappear. They lose energy (voltage drop) but continue flowing at the same rate.
principles.example: In a series circuit, the current before a resistor equals the current after the resistor.

principles.principle: Misconception: The largest resistor has the smallest current
principles.statement: Some think current divides based on resistance, like in parallel.
principles.application: In series, current is the same through all resistors. The largest resistor has the largest voltage drop, not a different current.
principles.example: A $100\ \Omega$ and a $10\ \Omega$ in series carry exactly the same current.

principles.principle: Misconception: Adding more resistors always decreases total resistance
principles.application: In series, adding more resistors INCREASES total resistance because you're adding more opposition to current flow.
principles.example: Two $10\ \Omega$ resistors in series give $20\ \Omega$, more than either alone.

principles.principle: Misconception: Voltage is the same across all resistors in series
principles.statement: Some think voltage distributes equally regardless of resistance.
principles.application: Voltage divides proportionally to resistance. Equal resistors get equal voltage; unequal resistors get different voltages.
principles.example: With $10\ \Omega$ and $20\ \Omega$ in series across $30\ \text{V}$, the $20\ \Omega$ gets $20\ \text{V}$, the $10\ \Omega$ gets $10\ \text{V}$.

principles.principle: Misconception: A break in a series circuit affects only that point
principles.statement: Students may think current can bypass an open component.
principles.application: In series, there's only one path. An open anywhere stops current everywhere.
principles.example: If one bulb burns out in a series string, all bulbs go dark.

summary: A series circuit connects components end-to-end, providing a single path for current flow. The key characteristics are: (1) Current is the same through all components: $I_{total} = I_1 = I_2 = I_3 = ...$ (2) Total resistance is the sum of individual resistances: $R_{eq} = R_1 + R_2 + R_3 + ...$ (3) Voltage drops add to the source voltage (Kirchhoff's Voltage Law): $V_{source} = V_1 + V_2 + V_3 + ...$ (4) Voltage divides proportionally to resistance: $V_n = I \times R_n$, with the largest resistor getting the largest voltage drop. The voltage divider formula for two resistors is $V_1 = V_{total} \times \frac{R_1}{R_1 + R_2}$. (5) Power dissipated by each resistor is $P = I^2R$, so power is proportional to resistance in series. Total power can be found from $P_{total} = V_{source} \times I$ or $P_{total} = I^2 R_{eq}$. Advantages of series circuits include simplicity, same current for all components, and easy voltage division. Disadvantages include complete failure if any component opens, and inability to operate components independently. Real-world applications include voltage dividers for sensors, current limiting resistors for LEDs, series battery connections to increase voltage, and protective devices like fuses and switches. Understanding series circuits is essential before studying parallel circuits, where current divides and voltage is constant.
